trial_identification.studytitle: Sing Your Lungs Out: Effect of community singing group on lung function, anxiety and depression, and health care use in patients with COPD who have completed pulmonary rehabilitation programme.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Sing Your Lungs Out: Effect of participation in weekly community singing group for 1 year, on lung function, anxiety and depression and health care use in patients with COPD who have completed pulmonary rehabilitation: a quantitative and qualitative study.

interventions.interventions: Weekly attendance at one hour community singing group for one year, (with register of attendance) having completed pulmonary rehabilitation.
interventions.comparator: We will compare number of acute exacerbations of COPD requiring hospital, GP or emergency attendance for each patient in the 12 months prior to joining the singing group,, with their health care use over the year of the SYLO study. Otherwise no controls.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Lung function: Spirometry, Lung volumes and 6 minute walk test. CCQ: Clinical COPD Questionnaire ( with permission)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline recordings 1 week prior to singing group attendance, then at 4 months and 1 year following commencement of intervention.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Anxiety and depression: HADs: Hospital Anxiety and Depression Score
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline recordings 1 week prior to singing group attendance, then at 4 months and 1 year following commencement of intervention.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Acute exacerbation of COPD requiring Hospital, GP or emergency department attendance : from electronic GP and hospital records.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline recordings 1 week prior to singing group attendance, then at 4 months and 1 year following commencement of intervention.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Qualitative description of individual interviews and focus group meeting with people participating in the singing group regarding their experience.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Six to nine months after starting with the singing group.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Have chronic lung disease and breathlessness. Have completed a CCDHB pulmonary rehabilitation programme and are attending a weekly maintenance exercise class
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Current enrolment in another clinical COPD trial.

trial_design.concealment: Patients with COPD who have completed CCDHB pulmonary rehabilitation were invited to join a weekly community singing group.
trial_design.statisticalmethods: This is a feasibility study to look at recruitment and estimate SD in a real population. 1. Basic descriptive statistics of this cohort sample of COPD Pulmonary rehabilitation patients. 2. Longitudinal data analysis of each individual looking at significant change in Lung function, HADscore and health care utilisation compared with baseline3. For patient interviews and focus group discussion: Qualitative content analysis of transcribed interviews using QDA miner. Analysis will be iterative allowing emerging themes to be explored in later interviews. Themes will be coded and categorised for analysis..

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This is a study looking at the potential health benefits to being part of a community based weekly singing group for patients with COPD who have completed pulmonary rehabilitation. We want to see if being part of a singing group sustains or even improves the health benefits of pulmonary rehabilitation.
